docs.snippet: New York State will start distributing a list of the 10 parents who owe the most money in child support payments in hopes of putting more pressure on delinquent parents, Gov. George E. Pataki said today.         The list is the latest measure by t...
docs.lead_paragraph: New York State will start distributing a list of the 10 parents who owe the most money in child support payments in hopes of putting more pressure on delinquent parents, Gov. George E. Pataki said today. The list is the latest measure by the Pataki administration to assure that parents pay what they owe in child support. The Governor also announced today that New York had collected nearly $2 million in child-support payments since it began suspending the driver's licenses of chronic nonpayers.

headline.main: Threat to Driver's Licenses Leads to More Child Support

docs.snippet: There seems to be something of a neglected-child syndrome in NBC's treatment  of "The John Larroquette Show." As the network's programming juggernaut scoops up powerful ratings, much is ballyhooed, justifiably, about "Seinfeld," "Friends," "E.R" a...
docs.lead_paragraph: There seems to be something of a neglected-child syndrome in NBC's treatment of "The John Larroquette Show." As the network's programming juggernaut scoops up powerful ratings, much is ballyhooed, justifiably, about "Seinfeld," "Friends," "E.R" and "Frasier." The Larroquette series tends to get reduced to a minor player. That's not so, in terms of either ratings or quality. Bumped around the NBC schedule for a couple of seasons, the show is now in the prime slot of Tuesdays at 9:30 P.M., immediately following "Frasier." There is a dip in the ratings as "Larroquette" comes on, but nothing disastrous. On a typical night it will still be ahead of "Wings" at 8 and the much vaunted "Dateline NBC" at 10. Obviously this is no 98-pound weakling.

headline.main: Working Days and Lightening Up at the Bus Depot

docs.snippet: Dr. Haing S. Ngor, a Cambodian physician who later won an Academy Award for his debut acting performance in the 1984 film "The Killing Fields," was shot to  death on Sunday night outside his home here.         The police said Dr. Ngor, whose own b...
docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Haing S. Ngor, a Cambodian physician who later won an Academy Award for his debut acting performance in the 1984 film "The Killing Fields," was shot to death on Sunday night outside his home here. The police said Dr. Ngor, whose own brutal experiences as a captive of the Khmer Rouge Government paralleled many of those undergone by the character he portrayed, died from chest wounds. His body was found about 8:45 P.M. slumped near his late-model Mercedes-Benz in the driveway of his modest two-bedroom apartment in a building near Chinatown. The area had had a problem with crime lately but residents said a strong police response appeared to have made it safer.

headline.main: Cambodian Physician Who Won an Oscar for 'Killing Fields' Is Slain

docs.snippet: After a year as the popular head of a non-elected Government, the outgoing Prime Minister, Lamberto Dini, has jumped squarely into Italy's pre-election politics, announcing he will lead a new party with center-left ties.         The party, which i...
docs.lead_paragraph: After a year as the popular head of a non-elected Government, the outgoing Prime Minister, Lamberto Dini, has jumped squarely into Italy's pre-election politics, announcing he will lead a new party with center-left ties. The party, which is yet to be named, will include several current top Government ministers and moderate political figures and is likely to be favored by the powerful financial and industrial establishment that had backed the Dini Government.

headline.main: Announcing New Party in Italy, Dini Jumps Into Election Fray

docs.snippet: Christopher Cross and Toto were bad enough, but Tony Bennett was the last straw.         That was the decision apparently reached last year by the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences, whose annual Grammy Awards have long been the most ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Christopher Cross and Toto were bad enough, but Tony Bennett was the last straw. That was the decision apparently reached last year by the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences, whose annual Grammy Awards have long been the most widely criticized of the entertainment industry's major awards shows. For years, critics have lambasted the Grammys for snubbing such trailblazers as the Beatles, the Rolling Stones and Bob Dylan, while honoring the likes of the Captain and Tennille (1975), Mr. Cross (1980) and Toto (1982). But not until last year, when Mr. Bennett's "MTV Unplugged" won the album of the year award, did the academy decide to change some crucial rules for the 38th annual awards ceremony, which will be held in Los Angeles on Wednesday. (It will be broadcast on CBS at 8 P.M.)

headline.main: Grammys Look for Hipness in New Rules

docs.snippet: To the final chords of Manolo Sanlucar's score for the ballet "Medea," the guest prima ballerina Lola Greco writhed in grief, her arms raised high as she pleaded to the gods for forgiveness for the murder of her children. A hush fell over the barn...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the final chords of Manolo Sanlucar's score for the ballet "Medea," the guest prima ballerina Lola Greco writhed in grief, her arms raised high as she pleaded to the gods for forgiveness for the murder of her children. A hush fell over the barnlike rehearsal space of the National Ballet of Spain. Though the dancers gathered on the sidelines were deeply familiar with Jose Granero's choreographic interpretation of the Greek tragedy, Ms. Greco had still brought them to tears. But only minutes later, the ballerina, who is Jose Greco's daughter, stood dolefully before Aurora Pons, Nana Lorca and Victoria Eugenia, the company's three regal artistic directors, who had watched the performance from a bench in the front of the room.

headline.main: Guarding the Purity of Traditional Spanish Dance

docs.snippet: A PROLIFERATION of secondary clothing lines in the last year shows that consumers are taking the reins of fashion from designers.         These alternative brands are more affordable, easier to maintain and less avant-garde than designers' premier...
docs.lead_paragraph: A PROLIFERATION of secondary clothing lines in the last year shows that consumers are taking the reins of fashion from designers. These alternative brands are more affordable, easier to maintain and less avant-garde than designers' premiere collections, reflecting the real wardrobe needs of women rather than designers' directional views.

headline.main: Real Clothes for Real Women (And at Lower Prices, Too)

docs.snippet: I grew up thinking of American presidents as godlike. Or at least saintlike.  And this is no exaggeration. A lot of us early boomers did, partly because of Franklin Delano Roosevelt, the hero of our parents generation who had not yet been demystif...
docs.lead_paragraph: I grew up thinking of American presidents as godlike. Or at least saintlike. And this is no exaggeration. A lot of us early boomers did, partly because of Franklin Delano Roosevelt, the hero of our parents generation who had not yet been demystified. But mostly because of the movies.

headline.main: Pols as Rats, But With Feelings

docs.snippet: Sir Freddie Laker, a British entrepreneur who was among the first to offer no-frills air travel in the 1970's, is about to start flying across the Atlantic again.         Sir Freddie plans to start Laker Airways as a charter service in late March,...
docs.lead_paragraph: Sir Freddie Laker, a British entrepreneur who was among the first to offer no-frills air travel in the 1970's, is about to start flying across the Atlantic again. Sir Freddie plans to start Laker Airways as a charter service in late March, offering flights from Orlando and Fort Lauderdale, Fla., to London, Manchester and Glasgow. As his airline grows, he said in a recent interview, he hopes to begin regularly scheduled service.

headline.main: The Laker Name Taking Off Again
